name: Starting Strength
desc: The focus is on building a foundation for your movement. You will mix and match strength and endurance, varying from 10 minutes a day to 35 minutes per day over a period of about 3 weeks.

tasks.name: About First Week
tasks.desc:
Welcome to a Beginning Strength Week - you can redo this playlist as many times as you wish - or using it in a progression - using it through 7 days and then move to the next Beginning Strength Week 2. If you find this session too easy for you this week, you are also welcome to move to other weeks. We'll also be adding new playlists to let you explore as well and try out other practices and progressions.

For now - starting on this day we'll overview what the coming week looks like:
 
Day 1 is learning strength moves and a bit of practice
Day 2 is learning mobility + and doing some endurance work (like walking)
Day 3 is a strength day using what you learned monday and adding some new mobility work 
Day 4 a minute more of mobility and then some endurance  
Day 5 another minute of mobility and doing the same strength moves from day 1 and day 3.

Strength will help your bones, tissues and muscles get stronger.
NeuroMoblitiy helps your brain learn more about these joints you may not be moving through their full ranges of motion - but when you do the brain really wakes up.
Endurance is building up the heart and lungs.
Putting it all together you help your gut, hormones and everything else inside too.

tasks.name: Find Your Lower Body Push
tasks.desc:
This is about a one minute video to show you how to find a LOWER BODY PUSH that you can do - by finding any lower body push move (usually called "squats" but not always) and then choosing to limit 
range of motion
speed 
load

one of those - to make it a sufficient challenge for you

tasks.name: FIND Your Upper Body Push
tasks.desc: This section helps you find an upper body, bodyweight only push that you can use to build whole body strength, but especially the upper body (from hips up -so including the mid section/6 pack area).

tasks.name: Upper and Lower Push -Bilaterals
tasks.desc:
This video demonstrates an EDT set putting together your Upper Body and Lower Body pushes. 

An EDT set is a type of "super set" - two moves - 5 repetitions of each move - done back to back with as little pause between the set - for time.

The rule of thumb is:

- find the level of each of your two moves that you can do for 10 reps (that's your 10 rep intensity)
- in the EDT set do FIVE of the first move (eg, squat) 
- pause -THAT's ONE SET
- do five reps of the second move (eg push up)
pause - that's your SECOND SET
repeat this cycle til the 7 minute timer goes off.

Count your sets and reps - and each time you do this EDT cycle, try to increase by a rep. 
That's the ESCALATING part - the DENSITY part is squeezing more reps into the same time.

tasks.name: NeuroMobility - Building Awareness of Self Locomotion
tasks.desc:
To help with both ENDURANCE and raw strength, neuromobility helps our brains learn where each joint is in space, relative to other joints, and how quickly that joint is moving. 

In this series we're adapting a movement series developed by Eric Cobb of ZhealthEducation, called "R-phase." The series moves through each joint in the body from toes to head to fingers, by taking these joints through their range of motion

tasks.name: Neuromobility: Toe Pulls
tasks.desc:
Watch first - then follow along - repeat if you wish 

You can do these movements throughout the day. Great to do first thing in the morning and before bed, too. 

- it's focusing on the foot via TOE LEVERAGE - three movements here: 
- middle toe pull
- outside toe pull
- inside toe pull

Keep a tall spine, relaxed shoulders - and explore where your foot needs to be to give you the nicest stretch 
1) top of your foot by the ankle
2) under the outer ankle
3) under the inner ankle (you may wish to put something soft under your big toe.

Again these moves are based on Eric Cobb's R-Phase Mobility, ZHealth.

tasks.name: Easy 30 - of any continuous movement
tasks.desc:
Take time out for a walk, run, bike, row, swim - any continuous motion activity.
Goal: breath in and out through your nose - if you need to breath through your mouth you're working too hard for this level.

tasks.name: FOLLOW Neuromovement: Ankle Tilts
tasks.desc:
Go ahead and play this first to see what the movements are and then follow along - 
As you learn these you can break them out and do them anytime, anywhere.

tasks.name: Upper and Lower Push
tasks.desc:
You can find the descriptions and overviews of EDT sets from Strength, Day 1.

This is a Bilateral PUSH day
lower body push + upper body push
5 + 5
repeat for time (7 minutes)

tasks.name: Exploring Endurance 2
tasks.desc: Today, we put together the neuromobility work we've learned so far, do some endurance work, then wrap up with the neuromobility.

tasks.name: Endurance - Practice Level
tasks.desc:
Here is where you head out for some ENDURANCE work - moving continuously but no harder than you can go, breathing in and out through your nose. 
Go for time -
